thread.title: Utes report card vs. Arizona State: Utah earns generally favorable reviews for hard-fought win
thread.title_full: Utes report card vs. Arizona State: Utah earns generally favorable reviews for hard-fought win | Deseret News

title: Utes report card vs. Arizona State: Utah earns generally favorable reviews for hard-fought win
text:
Here's a look at the grades for the Utes in their 34-18 victory over Arizona State on Saturday.
Upcoming Games Utah Football Utah   Utah @ USC Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, Los Angeles Oct. 24, 5:30 p.m. 6  Days   13  Hrs   57  Mins   40  Secs More Coverage Rock: With the Utes, it's always going to tie to Wilson Usually Utah's strength, special teams is Utes' weakness in victory over ASU No. 4 Utes surge late, remain unbeaten with 34-18 win over Arizona State Utes go to the air with Wilson on rainy night SALT LAKE CITY — Saturday night, No. 4 Utah and Arizona State squared off with first place in the Pac-12 South on the line in Salt Lake City.
In what many called a trap game for Utah, the Utes took care of business at home, beating the Sun Devils 34-18, and giving themselves a two-game cushion in the Pac-12 South standings.
Offense 
Utah racked up 369 yards of total offense, committed zero turnovers and scored 34 points Saturday night.
Travis Wilson played an excellent game, especially in the first half. Wilson completed 26-of-36 passes for 297 yards and two touchdowns on the night, hooking up with nine different receivers. The Sun Devils blitzed on what seemed like every down, trying to contain Devontae Booker and put the game on Wilson's shoulders. He responded in a big way with his best game of the season.
Arizona State was keen on stopping Utah's rushing attack, and limited Booker to 21 carries for 118 yards and two touchdowns. Booker was clutch in the fourth quarter, scoring both his touchdowns and helping the Utes outscore ASU 20-0 in the final period. Without his magical play in the final period, Booker had just 31 yards on 19 carries and zero touchdowns.
Grade: B+ 
Defense 
As it has been all season long, the Utah defense was absolutely fantastic. The Utes forced two turnovers — both in the fourth quarter — on their way to allowing just nine points and 257 yards of total offense.
There's not much else to say about this Utah defense except that it is, indeed, legit.
Grade: A+ 
Special teams 
Well ... this was one those nights where you would like to just forget you played special teams. That is unless your name is Andy Phillips or Tom Hackett.
Nine of ASU's 18 points were allowed by the Utah special teams. After leading 7-0, Utah kicked off to ASU return man Tim White. White went right to the sideline and went 100 yards untouched to tie the game 7-7. The coverage was poor to say the least, but unfortunately for Utah, it wasn't over.
Later, White stood back to receive a punt. He took it 48 yards and would have scored if Hackett wouldn't have made a touchdown-saving tackle.
In the third quarter, leading 14-13, Utah's Britain Covey received the kickoff nine yards deep in his own end zone. He then took off but stopped as if to take a knee before throwing an illegal forward pass to his left that resulted in a safety, giving the Sun Devils a 15-14 lead and the football.
It wasn't all bad for the Utes special teams, though. Phillips was 4-for-4 on field goal attempts, and Hackett punted eight times, landing five of them inside the 20.
Grade: C- 
Overall review 
After trailing 18-14, Utah outscored Arizona State 20-0 in the fourth quarter on its way to a 34-18 win. The defense was outstanding, the offense looked not so one dimensional and the special teams were disappointing.
But a win is a win. And Kyle Wittingham will take it any way he can. Utah sits at 6-0 overall and 3-0 in the Pac-12 heading into a clash with the USC Trojans next week.
Grade: A- 
CJ Pronk is a Deseret Digital Media contributor and a Stansbury High School graduate. He will be attending the University of Alabama and majoring in communications. Follow CJ on Twitter @BigCeeJ3113.
